entry.title: Ensuring Accurate Auto Delegation in SuccessFactors Using Validation Rules
entry.content:
Introduction

I received a requirement from one of our clients asking if we can setup a guardrail which prevents delegators from assigning Delegates outside their Department. This requirement is very valid because delegates outside the home department will not be aware of the operations in the home Department, so there's no point in assigning the workflows to someone who is not aware of the process which could result in trouble for both the business and delegates. Immediately, I got in to action referring to the Auto Delegation Config Object and Set up a Guardrail which solved the Purpose!

How This Was Achieved Using Business Rules

Technical Architecture

Step 1: Access the Auto Delegation Config Object

Navigate to Configure Object Definitions, search for Auto Delegation Config, and open the object. This Generic object is the foundation for storing auto-delegation setup information and the details related to it (Auto-Delegate Config Details).This is where the Guardrails should be Set up.

Step 2: Create and Assign a On Save Business Rule

Next, create a on Save Business Rule that validates the delegate‚Äôs department against the delegator‚Äôs department. The rule checks whether both Employees belong to the same department. If not, the system triggers a validation error and prevents the record from being saved.


This rule can be customized further to include alternative or additional criteria depending on business needs.

Step 3: Configure Auto Delegation Using the Quick Action

Once the rule is assigned under the On Save rules of the Auto Delegation Config object, users can proceed to set up their auto-delegation via the Quick Action available on the SuccessFactors home page. The validation will run during the On-Save Action every time a delegator attempts to assign a delegate and validates the Delegator Department against the Delegatee Department

Conclusion

Guardrails always prevent and handle unforeseen scenarios. This guardrail here configured to validate department helps businesses maintain operational efficiency and keeps the business workflow moving intact!

Business Rules are the Core Engine behing SAP SuccessFactors and there's so much that can be done with Business Rules! Keep Exploring and Share how this has helped with your Organization!

@GOPIKA_SB Thanks for Coming up with this One! It really intrigued me!

entry.title: Re: Value Mapping usage in XSLT Mappings with CPI
entry.content:
I have combined all steps in one groovy script:

def Message readValueMapping(Message message) {
def map = message.getProperties();
def iAgency = "SF";
def iIdentifier = "inCountry";
def inputValue;
def oAgency = "Unit4";
def oIdentifier = "outCountry";

def VMservice = ITApiFactory.getService(ValueMappingApi.class, null);

// Parse incoming XML
def xml = new XmlParser().parseText(message.getBody(String));


// Loop through each User node
xml.User.each { user ->
inputValue = user.country.text();

if( VMservice != null)
{
def mappedValue = VMservice.getMappedValue(iAgency, iIdentifier, inputValue, oAgency, oIdentifier);
user.country[0].value = mappedValue;
}
}

// Write XML without formatting (no newlines / indentation)
def writer = new StringWriter()
def printer = new XmlNodePrinter(new PrintWriter(writer))
printer.preserveWhitespace = true
printer.print(xml)

// Remove any remaining line breaks or extra spaces
def compactXml = writer.toString()
.replaceAll(">\\s+<", "><")
.replaceAll("\\r|\\n", "")

// Set compact XML as message body
message.setBody(compactXml)

return message;
}

 

üôÇ

entry.title: Cloud ALM - Tasks and subtasks view
entry.content:
Hi, 

I'm trying to get familiar with the tasks/subtasks-function in Cloud ALM as this seems promising. 

But I wonder if it is any way to view the subtasks connected to the tasks in the table view? 
This works great in the gantt-view, but the relation between the task and subtask is not well visualized in the table view. 

Example: 

I have created two tasks (A and B), with respective subtasks structured like this: 

Task A
- Subtask A1
- Subtask A2

Task B
- Subtask B1
- Subtask B2

When viewing this in the gantt-view this is presented perfectly like this: 


But when viewing this in the table-view, the tasks are sorted by themselves, and then all the subtasks are sorted by themselves like this. 


As the relation between the task and subtask is not visualized this gets quite messy when you have a lot of tasks / subtasks. 

Is there any way to set up this in table view, so that the sub-tasks are placed under the task that it is related to, like in the gantt-view?

entry.title: Invoice Submission to the Singapore Tax Authority: How to Automate Invoice Note Filling in XML Files
entry.content:
Are you a GST-registered business in Singapore subject to the GST InvoiceNow Requirement? If so, you need to submit invoice data electronically to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS). This may include providing invoice notes in XML files submitted to IRAS. This blog provides guidance on how you can automate this step.

A few quick notes:

  • SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition is the solution to support GST InvoiceNow requirements. For an overview, check out this blog: SAP Document and Reporting Compliance for Singapore GST InvoiceNow.
  • This blog applies to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, SAP S/4HANA, and SAP ERP.
  • This blog quotes information from some IRAS guidelines. The quoted information is accurate as of the publication date of the blog. As these IRAS guidelines are subject to change, we recommend checking the latest versions for the most current information.

 

What Is an Invoice Note?

Here‚Äôs the definition of invoice note from TX2 - Annex - Data Specification:

A textual note that gives unstructured information that is relevant to the Invoice as a whole such as the reason for any correction or assignment note in case the invoice has been factored.

An invoice note is displayed in one of these XML elements, depending on the invoice type:

  • ubl:Invoice / cbc:Note for invoices
  • ubl:CreditNote / cbc:Note for credit notes

IRAS specifies the scenarios where an invoice note is mandatory, such as credit notes and self-billing invoices. For certain special scenarios, IRAS prescribes their note texts. For example, according to the e-Tax Guide ‚ÄúAdopting GST InvoiceNow Requirement for GST-registered Businesses (First Edition)‚Äù, you must include this exact note text in self-billing invoices:

The invoice is a Buyer Created Tax Invoice. The tax shown is your output tax due to the Comptroller of GST.

 

The Challenge: Automating Beyond the Standard

To include an invoice note in a submitted XML file, you need to enter the note text in a specific source document field. For those scenarios that require specific note texts, it would be a great time-saver if the system can fill in them automatically. The standard solution already does this for these scenarios:

  • Self-billing invoices
  • Customer invoices with the GST category code SRCA-S (Customer accounting supply made by supplier)
  • Supplier invoices with the GST category code TXCA (Standard-rated purchases of prescribed goods subject to customer accounting)

What about other scenarios? Manually entering invoice notes is really time-consuming and prone to error.

 

The Solution: BAdI to the Rescue

You can define your own logic for populating invoice notes using the following Business Add-Ins (BAdIs):

ProductBAdI
  • SAP S/4HANA
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
  • SAP ERP
EDOC_ADAPTOR: SET_OUTPUT_DATA method
SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public EditionEDOC_ADAPTOR_Cloud: SET_OUTPUT_DATA method

In this blog, we'll show you how to create a BAdI implementation that populates invoice notes for customer invoices (eDocument type: SGC5C_INV) in these scenarios based on the tax code:

ScenarioInvoice Note Text Prescribed by IRASTax Code You Use
Gross Margin SchemeThe transaction is under the Gross Margin Scheme.S1
Approved Marine Fuel Trader SchemeThe Payment of GST is not required under the AMFT Scheme.Z1
Discounted Sale Price SchemeThe transaction is under the Discounted Sale Price Scheme.Z2

 

Step-by-Step Guide: Sample BAdI Implementation in SAP S/4HANA, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, and SAP ERP

Step 1: Create a customer package.

Some objects are created when you create a BAdI implementation. To transport these objects across a customer landscape, create a customer package or choose an existing customer package.

Step 2: Create an enhancement implementation.

In this example, we create an implementation named ZEI_EDOC_ADAPTOR_SG_C5 by doing the following:

  1. Call up the SE19 transaction.
  2. Select the New BAdI radio button in the Create Implementation section and enter ES_EDOCUMENT in the Enhancement Spot field. Choose Create.



  3. Enter ZEI_EDOC_ADAPTOR_SG_C5 as the enhancement implementation name and Implementation: eDocument Adaptor Singapore as the short text. Choose Continue.



    When prompted for a package, enter the package created or chosen in step 1.

  4. In the window that appears next, do the following:
    • Enter ZEI_EDOC_ADAPTOR_SG_C5 as the BAdI implementation name.
    • Enter ZCL_EDOC_ADAPTOR_SG_C5 as the implementation class.
    • Select the BAdI definition EDOC_ADAPTOR.

  5. Choose Continue. When prompted for a package, enter the package created or chosen in step 1.
  6. Activate your changes.
  7. Expand the tree for the BAdI implementation you just created. Double-click Filter Values.



  8. In the filter values details on the right, choose Create Filter Combination. 



  9. In the Choose Filter dialog, select COUNTRY. Choose Continue.
  10. Double-click the COUNTRY filter.
  11. In the Display Filter Value dialog, enter SG as Value 1 and select = as Comparator 1. Choose Continue.



    The filter combination you just created looks like this: 



Step 3: Update the ZCL_EDOC_ADAPTOR_SG_C5 class.

  1. Call up the SE24 transaction.
  2. Enter the object type ZCL_EDOC_ADAPTOR_SG_C5. Choose Change.



  3. Double-click the method IF_EDOC_ADAPTOR~SET_OUTPUT_DATA.



  4. Add the sample code below into this method:
        FIELD-SYMBOLS: <fs_mwskz> TYPE mwskz,
                       <fs_tax_data_tab> TYPE any,
                       <fs_tax_data> TYPE any.

        io_source->get_data_reference(
          RECEIVING
            rd_data = DATA(lv_data)
        ).

        IF lv_data IS NOT INITIAL.
          ASSIGN COMPONENT 'TAX_DATA' OF STRUCTURE lv_data->* to <fs_tax_data_tab>.
          IF <fs_tax_data_tab> IS ASSIGNED.
            LOOP AT <fs_tax_data_tab> ASSIGNING <fs_tax_data>.
              ASSIGN COMPONENT 'MWSKZ' OF STRUCTURE <fs_tax_data> TO <fs_mwskz>.
              IF sy-subrc = 0.
                CASE <fs_mwskz>.
                  WHEN 'S1'.
                        IF iv_edoc_type = 'SGC5C_INV'.
                            output_inv-invoice-note-base-base-content = 'The transaction is under the Gross Margin Scheme.'.
                            cs_output_data = output_inv.
                        ENDIF.
                  WHEN 'Z1'.
                        IF iv_edoc_type = 'SGC5C_INV'.
                            output_inv-invoice-note-base-base-content = 'The Payment of GST is not required under the AMFT Scheme.'.
                            cs_output_data = output_inv.
                        ENDIF.
                  WHEN 'Z2'.
                        IF iv_edoc_type = 'SGC5C_INV'.
                            output_inv-invoice-note-base-base-content = 'The transaction is under the Discounted Sale Price Scheme.'.
                            cs_output_data = output_inv.
                        ENDIF.
                  WHEN OTHERS.
                ENDCASE.
              ENDIF.
            ENDLOOP.
          ENDIF.
        ENDIF.‚Äã


5. Save and activate your changes.

 

Guidance for Customers Using SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

You need to add the sample code below into the SET_OUTPUT_DATA method of the EDOC_ADAPTOR_Cloud BAdI:

Tip: 
For a step-by-step guide on how to implement this BAdI, check out the following blog:
Enhancing the Standard XML File for Electronic Documents using the BAdI EDOC_ADAPTOR_CLOUD 

 

        FIELD-SYMBOLS: <fs_mwskz> TYPE mwskz,
                       <fs_tax_data_tab> TYPE any,
                       <fs_tax_data> TYPE any.

        io_source->get_data_reference(
          RECEIVING
            rd_data = DATA(lv_data)
        ).

        IF lv_data IS NOT INITIAL.
          ASSIGN COMPONENT 'TAX_DATA' OF STRUCTURE lv_data->* to <fs_tax_data_tab>.
          IF <fs_tax_data_tab> IS ASSIGNED.
            LOOP AT <fs_tax_data_tab> ASSIGNING <fs_tax_data>.
              ASSIGN COMPONENT 'MWSKZ' OF STRUCTURE <fs_tax_data> TO <fs_mwskz>.
              IF sy-subrc = 0.
                CASE <fs_mwskz>.
                  WHEN 'S1'.
                        IF iv_edoc_type = 'SGC5C_INV'.
                            output_inv-invoice-note-base-base-content = 'The transaction is under the Gross Margin Scheme.'.
                            cs_output_data = output_inv.
                        ENDIF.
                  WHEN 'Z1'.
                        IF iv_edoc_type = 'SGC5C_INV'.
                            output_inv-invoice-note-base-base-content = 'The Payment of GST is not required under the AMFT Scheme.'.
                            cs_output_data = output_inv.
                        ENDIF.
                  WHEN 'Z2'.
                        IF iv_edoc_type = 'SGC5C_INV'.
                            output_inv-invoice-note-base-base-content = 'The transaction is under the Discounted Sale Price Scheme.'.
                            cs_output_data = output_inv.
                        ENDIF.
                  WHEN OTHERS.
                ENDCASE.
              ENDIF.
            ENDLOOP.
          ENDIF.
        ENDIF.

 

Wrapping Up

Hope this blog is helpful for you. We'd love to hear feedback from you. Feel free to share comments below. Let's learn from each other!

To learn more about the solution, refer to the following documentation on SAP Help Portal, which covers business task procedures, configuration, and more:

ProductDocumentation Links
SAP S/4HANA, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
  • Electronic Customer Invoices: Submission to the Tax Authority
  • Electronic Supplier Invoices: Submission to the Tax Authority
SAP ERP
  • Electronic Customer Invoices: Submission to the Tax Authority
  • Electronic Supplier Invoices: Submission to the Tax Authority
SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • Electronic Customer Invoices: Submission to the Tax Authority
  • Electronic Supplier Invoices: Submission to the Tax Authority

entry.title: Assessing the number of messages in SAP integration Suite
entry.content:
Most of the developers overlook that the billing of iflows is based on the number of messages rather than the iflow design object or number of Users. 

While designing an iflow a judicious choice of Multicast has to be taken into account. 

The moment the multicast is used, it will split a message into a copy of a message and increase the count of messages created in the iflow. 

Also. While creating a solution for successfactors, one optimization can be using AEM brokered rather than point to point SF querying interfaces.

entry.title: Re: Making control recipe destination as optional in Recipe
entry.content:
Namaste!

In SAP standard, you can eliminate the need to maintain control recipe destinations in master recipes (and the corresponding process orders using a master recipe profile like PI01_XS (for details see SAP help). If this profile is chosen, no control recipe destinations need to be maintained in the operation/phase overview of the master recipe/process order. If you have assigned such a profile (or changed it from profile PI01), you will recognize a white "ice cube" icon appearing in the icon bar of the operation/phase overview. Clicking on the "ice cube" icon will open the so called XStep editor (XSteps = Execution Steps). To prevent the mandatory control recipe destination maintenance, you need to maintain a simple XStep tree root node in the XStep editor. So, click on the "ice cube" icon.  If you do not want to use PP-PI process management features (PP-PI-PMA), just create the XStep tree toot node by clicking on the corresponding button in the XStep editor. Then save your changes.

Process orders that you create from such master recipes will not force you to maintain control recipe destinations in the operation/phase overview. Because the XStep tree root node of the master recipe is automatically copied from the master recipe.

Remarks:

  • Using profiles like PI01_XS, the existence of the XStep tree root node in the master recipe/process order is mandatory. Because if such a profile is applied, the system will check for the existence of an XStep tree (root node). If no XStep tree root node is detected, the system will set the control recipe destination column to mandatory again.
    • Reason for this behavior: To smoothen transitions from the classical characteristic-based process instructions to XSte-based ones, customers can choose a master recipe profile where XStep usage is allowed, but not mandatory. This profile can be assigned to master recipes to determine the point in time for a migration: So, you can start with the old way to maintain your process instructions using the corresponding sub-menu of the operation/phase overview. When you decide to move on to XSteps, you just create your XStep tree data including your XStep tree(s) root node(s). At that point in time, the XStep data "overrules" the maintained content of the characteristic-based process instructions. And the column for the control recipe destination maintenance in the operation/phase overview is no longer mandatory. If you use XStep-based process instructions, the control recipe destinations are maintained in the XStep tree. This data is stored separately from the process order/master recipe.
    • Of course, you can also create dummy control recipe destinations (transaction O10C) and assign them to the master recipes/process orders in the usual way. But take care not to use dummy control recipe destinations of destination type 1 (ABAP-list based PI Sheets). ABAP-list based PI Sheets are outdated since 1999, and you cannot maintain or use them in SAP S/4HANA. So, you rather choose the destinations of type 2, 3, 4, or X (X available since SAP S/4HANA 2023, FPS01).

entry.title: Santa learns lessons from the past: Successful Agentic AI needs an Event Driven Architecture
entry.content:
Most organisations realise that Agentic AI will become critical to their business. But there is still hesitation about giving up more control to these new agents. What if they make bad decisions, what if they do the wrong thing ?

I‚Äôve been in the technology industry for more decades than I may care to admit. Before joining SAP, I spent 14 years working within Financial Services and Capital Markets. It is interesting to reflect on those times. Many of the challenges back then remain the same today.

In Financial Services, the major players did not hesitate to innovate with new technology ‚Äì for them it was opportunity. Very early on they realised that trading in ‚Äúsimpler‚Äù financial instruments ( e.g. foreign exchange ) did not really need humans shouting excitedly at one another on the (tele)phone. That trading was quickly handed over to computers ‚Äì and whilst it was perhaps not AI by today‚Äôs definition, it was certainly algorithmic and it was most definitely autonomous. Billions still gets traded by these Agentic AI predecessors, all based on the lightning-fast decisions they make ( but operating within parameters and thresholds defined by humans that quantify the risk ).

Decisions are made as a result of an event that arises. Better decisions are made knowing the wider context of that event. Yes, context comes from data. Wider context ( surprise ! ) comes from more and different data. But all that data needs to be super up-to-date, and accurate.

Financial Services firms understood and solved this also. In a 24x7 global market, there is no window for a batch run to load data. Trading systems, market data providers, stock exchanges, market and credit risk systems and more, all needed to be wired together for simultaneous update of data. Plus, it needed to be robust and flexible to add-in other market participants and their systems also.

Most firms adopted architectures built around messaging-oriented middleware, with technologies like Enterprise Service Bus, Message Queue, and Event Bus amongst others, all being variations on a theme that today we call an Event Driven Architecture (EDA). Their appetite for speed pushed the technology to milli-second response times and super high-availability. Equally valuable was that the decoupled publisher-subscriber model allowed much faster and easier recovery if any of the participants in their expanded trading ecosystem did experience a failure.

Perhaps such requirements seem a bit extreme for many companies operating in other industry segments. But the world is increasingly real time for the majority of businesses, and as Agentic AI plays a bigger part in your daily operations, it may be time to reflect on these lessons.

To highlight this more tangibly, I thought about a festive ( but fictional ? ) example where the capabilities of an Event Driven Architecture could really make a difference. So grab a coffee, something sweet to eat ( save the gym for the New Year ) and read on ‚Ä¶

 

Santa Inc refactors gift delivery on an Event Driven Architecture

After decades relying on delivery to every home in sequence, Santa has realised this will no longer scale and he risks missing targets and some serious reputational damage. His operations used to be ok, but the customer base expands every year and getting to all of those in one day is now stretching the imagination.

Production used to be straightforward when it was just teddy bears, dolls, drums and toy trains, but now with games consoles, smartphones and other sophisticated presents it has become necessary to outsource to specialised manufacturing facilities in many countries. The elves have switched roles from sewing and carpentry to now managing supply chains, delivery bottlenecks and stock-outs ‚Äì they‚Äôre stressed and threatening to go on strike ! Managing stock and purchasing was much easier when children used to write letters, but now they post their wish lists on social media ‚Äì and keep changing their minds based on what is trending ! Logistics was never a problem ‚Äì Rudolph and the other reindeer managed through even the harshest weather. But now they are obliged to adhere to air-traffic control diversions and compulsory rest stops. Finally, when delivering a present, it was disappointing to find out  ( too late ) that the child had been naughty rather than nice. It meant carrying extra payload on the sleigh and unnecessary manufacturing and purchase costs.

Santa has an extensive IT landscape and ecosystem. But he realised even his magical powers were no longer the answer ‚Äì it was time to transform his operations. But not rip and replace ‚Ä¶ even with 364 quieter days, that would still be too much work. Besides, most of the individual systems did what they needed to do ‚Äì it was just they didn‚Äôt really react to each other that well. There was a lot of point-to-point connection between the production, inventory, CRM and other systems, with each repeatedly polling the other for updates ‚Äì a real spaghetti architecture. Adding new suppliers‚Äô systems into this landscape was slow. Recovering from any one system failure, having to replay lost transactions and regain overall confidence in stock quantities and delivery shipments an even bigger nightmare.

All of this was putting huge pressure on the elves. Santa has always been committed to his workforce, and he wanted the team to be happy and motivated. He looked to Agentic AI to help them, to manage the scale and complexity of supply chains. But like his elves, those AI agents would need to be super-smart, reactive, and always up to date with reliable data.

And then the lightbulb went on for Santa. He was reading this article about Event Driven Architecture and realised that would answer so many of these problems. The synchronous and repeated point-to-point communication is taken away. Instead, events are published asynchronously, with brokers distributing and guaranteeing them, to be consumed by any system that is interested ‚Äì instantly ( super-fast ) and simultaneously ( not each system in turn ). The spaghetti is now replaced by something more like a giant distributed smorgasbord in which everyone ( elves, agents and ecosystem partners ) can share all at once. NOTE: Santa was never a fan of spaghetti but does quite enjoy a good smorgasbord.

With an Event Driven Architecture, Santa could be much more responsive in his production runs and purchasing. Plus, new suppliers could be on-boarded quickly and easily to cater for peaks in toy popularity, as well as getting up-to-date pricing and costs across his ecosystem. On the big night itself, so many of those delivery headaches could now be mitigated. Travel and weather alerts would be provided immediately for dynamic routing updates ( and for Santa, every milli-second matters ). Add to this a real-time feed of naughty-or-nice monitoring data being gathered by event brokers across the globe ( some in very remote locations ) and made available to the dynamic routing algorithm as well as stock logistics teams ( Santa has an increasing network of warehouses that he needs to stop at ‚Äì he cannot carry everything on his sleigh ).

Santa and his Enterprise Architect ( another Elf ) looked at options and decided on SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh. Given that 84% of the world‚Äôs global commerce runs on SAP systems, and these already have high-value business events out-of-the-box, it was likely that much of Santa‚Äôs ecosystem could be easily included. Even for those using other vendors‚Äô applications, the solution was open to those via industry-standard protocols, plus it was possible to include custom-built events. It did not need rip and replace, and the system could scale by adding more brokers over time to create an event mesh. Even better, that same infrastructure could be used for other event use cases ( Santa wondered about moving into Travel & Entertainment for the rest of the year ‚Äì perhaps offering trips on the sleigh into low earth orbit ‚Äì he thought that might become popular ).

Whilst looking at SAP, his Enterprise Architect saw SAP Build Joule Studio, to create the AI agents. That seemed an obvious choice also ‚Äì many processes would run on SAP, the most relevant and up-to-date operational data resides there, plus it offered a large choice of LLMs across the major providers. Quick to get into production also ‚Äì because they rapidly needed to regain morale amongst the elves.

So that‚Äôs the story of how one globally recognised brand came to explore the benefits of an Event Driven Architecture. If you recognise any similarities to challenges within your own business operation, then I would invite you learn more here. Or, if you would like to see an example that the elves built earlier, then please do look at this short demo.

entry.title: The Future of Supply Chain Management | Part 6 of 6
entry.content:
Supply Chain 2035: How Will Everyday Work Change in the Future of the Supply Chain?

In the first five parts of this joint series, SAP Business Consulting and K√ºhne Logistics University examined various aspects of the supply chain of the future. In this sixth and final part, we discuss how the everyday work of supply chain managers will change. Key technological drivers include the rapid spread of artificial intelligence (AI) and cloud technologies. This is reinforced by a socioeconomic trend: a shortage of skilled workers. While the knowledge required to handle many tasks is becoming increasingly specialized, demographic developments are shrinking the available workforce. This is already leading to highly polarizing views: on one side, some fear that many workers could lose their jobs to AI; on the other, many see AI as the best hope for staying competitive and overcoming new challenges amid the emerging shortage of skilled employees.

The reality will vary by employee and company. Although reliable forecasts are difficult given the rapid pace of change, three developments are already noticeable today. First, the range of tasks in Supply Chain Management will shift from operational to strategic activities. Second, the interaction between people and technology will change significantly. Finally, education and training for the Supply Chain Managers of the future will ‚Äì and must ‚Äì change.

Shifting the range of tasks from operational to strategic activities

With ongoing digitalization and use of AI, manual work is already shrinking in employees‚Äô daily routines. By 2035, many companies will automate most routine decisions across the end-to-end supply chain ‚Äì from demand forecasting and purchase order processing to dynamic route planning in logistics. Time once spent on ‚Äútransaction‚Äù work ‚Äì collecting, cleaning, reviewing, and documenting ‚Äì will shift to coordinating a system of data platforms, decision intelligence, and AI agents.

This shifts the focus of tasks:

  • From execution to design: People set objectives, guidelines, and policies for how systems act, and design the decision logic (‚Äúguardrails‚Äù) for trade-offs across price, volume, service, and sustainability.
  • From reaction to anticipation: The focus moves to scenario planning, Digital Twin simulations, and portfolio choices (e.g., higher service level versus less capital tied up).
  • From KPIs to Outcomes: Move from purely operational metrics (e.g., on-time delivery at the level of individual orders) to results-focused targets such as risk-adjusted contribution margin, customer experience, resilience levels, and sustainability impact.

The day-to-day work of 2035 becomes more strategic: In the morning, the Control-Tower environment offers an overview of the situation with current risks, opportunities, and suggestions from AI agents. Employees talk with colleagues and copilots to understand the impact of different scenarios (e.g., a supplier outage on high-margin segments), adjust policies (such as safety stocks in critical regions), run experiments in the Digital Twin, and make a few exceptional but high-impact decisions. This is accompanied by new roles such as Network Orchestrator, Scenario Strategist for end-to-end decisions, and Data Steward.

Changing how people and technology work together

Based on these changes, it‚Äôs clear that technology will move from being just a tool for completing tasks to being a partner working alongside people. The following focus areas are already emerging:

  • Copilots instead of masks: natural-language, context-enabled assistants explain suggestions, simulate alternatives, and implement policy changes. Prompting shifts from ad‚Äëhoc commands to structured briefs that state the goal, constraints, and evaluation criteria.
  • Explainability and uncertainty: Recommendations include clear justifications, key drivers, confidence levels, and uncertainty ranges. Explainable AI and standard why/what‚Äëif reports become the norm to build trust and support audits.
  • Continuous learning: Systems learn from everyday use. Employees provide structured feedback that flows into the models and further improves the results.

As employees hand over more control and responsibility to technology, governance needs extra care. This includes using agent-on-agent controls (agents that monitor other agents) and setting clear human release criteria and approval steps.

The training of the supply chain managers of the future

The described role shifts and the new form of interaction require a profound change in training and further development. The ideal supply chain manager of the future will mix deep business experience with fluency in new tools and adaptability. As one interviewee put it: ‚ÄúWe need a person who is experienced and young. Experienced, in the sense that she knows the company and the products and stays calm when something unexpected happens. Young, in the sense that she knows all new tools and technologies and is flexible enough to adapt to new possibilities. ‚Äú

Although this can be covered by a team rather than by individuals, it also suggests that T-shaped profiles will be in high demand in the future: a broad set of basic digital competencies combined with deep domain expertise. Everyone in the future supply chain should understand the end-to-end processes, identify the dependencies, optimize the network as a whole, and stay current on rapid tech advances.

Therefore, we recommend that in the future training and further training be more cross-functional ‚Äì with stations in purchasing, production, logistics, sales and data & analytics. At the same time, employees should be trained with technology-enabled learning in the context of work. This includes building learning environments where new technologies, methods, and concepts can be applied and reflected directly in the work process. The focus is less on formal training, but on the ability to experiment with digital tools, to critically question their results and to derive impulses to improve processes and decisions.

Conclusion: The Supply Chain Managers of 2035

In 2035, Supply Chain Managers will spend less time on routine transactions and more on building and running complex, connected decision-making environments. Technology will act as a true team member ‚Äì preparing options, executing decisions, and learning from outcomes within clear guardrails. People remain the decisive success factor: bringing sharpened strategic judgment, strong data and technology fluency, a deep sense of responsibility, and the ability to orchestrate ecosystems. Organizations that embrace this transformation now will not only become more productive and resilient but also build supply chains that deliver sustainable competitive advantage.

Figure (AI generated): The interaction between humans and technology is shifting from a focus on transactional data to dialog-based copilots.

This article was written in collaboration with Prof. Kai Hoberg (K√ºhne Logistics University) in the context of the SAP-KLU study "The Supply Chain of the Future.‚Äù

Part 1: How Future Supply Chain Management Works
Part 2: How Data, AI, and Agents are Changing Supply Chain Planning
Part 3: Is Artificial Intelligence Determining Future Purchasing?
Part 4: The Factory of the Future: Production in the Age of AI, Circular Economy, and Autonomous Systems
Part 5: The New Era of Logistics: AI and Robotics in Action?

entry.title: Differentiate free-of-charge vs standard deliveries at outbound delivery header in SAP Public Cloud
entry.content:
We are working in an SAP Public Cloud environment and facing the following challenge in the Warehouse Monitor:
Outbound delivery documents use the same delivery type (LF) for both processes ‚Äì standard sales and free-of-charge deliveries. At the outbound delivery header, we cannot find any field or criterion to differentiate these two types of deliveries.

The only difference we currently see is at the item level, where the item category differs:

  • TAN = standard sales
  • CBXN = free-of-charge delivery

However, there is no way to distinguish them at the header level, and in SAP Public Cloud there is a restriction that we cannot create a new delivery type.

Question:
Is there any way to differentiate free-of-charge deliveries from standard sales deliveries at the outbound delivery header in EWM? Can we add a custom field or use another approach (e.g., BAdI, extensibility options)? Has anyone faced this scenario and found a solution in the Public Cloud environment?

Thanks in advance for your help!

entry.title: How to Show Previous Year (Same Month) Date in Dynamic Text Using Story Filter in SAP SAC
entry.content:
Hello everyone!!!

I have an SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) analytic story where a story-level date filter (not an input control) is applied on a posting date dimension.

In this story, I have two tables:

  • Table 1 displays data for the currently selected date from the story filter.

  • Table 2 displays data for the same month of the previous year, which has already been achieved.

Now, I need to align this logic with dynamic text boxes placed above each table.

For Table 1, the requirement is straightforward. The dynamic text directly fetches the selected date from the story filter and displays it with a message, for example:
‚ÄúBalance Sheet as on April, 25‚Äù (Month, YY)

For Table 2, I need a second dynamic text box that displays the same month but previous year, derived from the same story filter selection. For example:
‚ÄúBalance Sheet as on April, 24‚Äù(Month, YY)

The key constraints are:

  • The date selection comes from a story filter, not an input control.

  • Dynamic text should be driven by the same story filter selection.

I would like to understand the recommended and supported approach in SAC to derive and display the previous year (same month) date in a dynamic text box, based on a story-level date filter.

Any guidance, best practices, or scripting-based solutions would be highly appreciated.

entry.title: Re: Route determination in Standard Purchase Order
entry.content: Not sure, in which version you are working. Private or Public Cloud. Please note for TM integration, SAP expects the PO to trigger an inbound delivery, and the delivery carries the transportation data (route, shipping condition, loading date). If you are in S/4, SAP TM can determine the required route to an in-bound delivery being triggered from PO. On the other hand, if you want this custom validation at PO header level, then, you need to go with available BAdIs

  • SAP for Energy & Utilities Conference (Toulouse, April 21‚Äì23, 2026): Advanced‚Äëaccess pricing is available until January 15, 2026. The workshop's agenda is live, and the main conference agenda will be available soon.

  • Catch up on expert‚Äëled Espresso Sessions and on‚Äëdemand webinars on the convergence of enterprise data, generative AI, and in-depth industry solutions.

Additional highlights include next-generation kitting and staging for MRO, as well as guidance on aligning with ISO 55001 and SAP Intelligent Asset Management.

Customer transformations:

  • ExxonMobil advanced its fit‚Äëto‚Äëstandard strategy and modernized finance consolidation with SAP Group Reporting on SAP S/4HANA, leveraging SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP).
  • S‚ÄëOIL accelerated growth and efficiency with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition via RISE with SAP.
  • CGC harmonized processes and culture using SAP Signavio and SAP LeanIX, supported by SAP Enable Now and SAP UEM by Knoa.

entry.title: Re: Assign quantity as Overridable Field in pricing tree
entry.content:
Hi Ankit, 

although you can define overridable fields of type Quantity and String in a price element specification it is not supported in within Subscription Billing. Only overwritable fields of type Price Condition within Subscription Billing.
If you want to transfer values for fields ot type Quantity or String, then you have to define this in the pricing field mapping for the pricing scheme within the Business Configuration app. In the context of a subscription item, you can use

  • Custom references for fields of type String
  • Product Configuration for fields of type String, Quantity and Date

Does this meet your requirement?

Best regards,
Carsten

entry.title: Accelerate Your SAP Transformation Journey: Enablement Offerings You Shouldn't Miss
entry.content:
Ready to Transform?

The following enablement offerings are designed to empower you with the knowledge and tools needed to drive successful transformation initiatives. Whether you're just starting or deep into your journey, continuous learning is key to unlocking long-term value.

In today‚Äôs fast-evolving landscape, moving to the cloud is no longer optional - it‚Äôs essential to stay competitive. The cloud offers scalability, cost efficiency, enhanced security, and access to advanced technologies like AI, while also improving customer experiences. But cloud transformation is not just about technology; it‚Äôs about enabling agility, innovation, and responsiveness to change.

The Challenge: Navigating Complexity in the Cloud Journey

  • How to transition to the cloud safely, quickly, and cost-effectively?
  • Where SAP‚Äôs guidance for a smooth transformation can be found?
  • How to minimize disruption and mitigate risk?
  • Which path is right for our business?
  • How to move to RISE with SAP?

 These are not just technical questions - they are business-critical decisions.

The Answer: SAP Business Transformation Center

To address these challenges, SAP has introduced the SAP Business Transformation Center‚Äîa unified, intelligent platform designed to accelerate and de-risk the journey to the cloud. At its core, the Business Transformation Center offers a proven five-step methodology, built on decades of SAP expertise, co-innovation with customers and partners, and deep integration with SAP Cloud ALM.

A Proven Five-Step Approach to Cloud Success

  1. AI-Powered Transition Recommendations
    Start with the Transformation Approach Finder app, which uses data-driven insights to identify the best-fit transition path tailored to your unique requirements.
  2. Digital Blueprinting for Clarity and Control
    Create a visual, interactive, and traceable foundation for your transformation with the Digital Blueprint enabling precise scoping and documentation.
  3. Streamlined System Transition
    Use the RISE with SAP System Transition Workbench to automate and safeguard your system move, ensuring minimal downtime and maximum reliability. Benefit from extensive automation and guaranteed downtime when moving to the cloud. Read the blogpost.
  4. Flexible Data Transition Options
    Execute the right data migration strategy based on the Find Transformation Approach app:
    • System Conversion with Software Update Manager (including Downtime Optimized Conversion)
    • Selective Data Transition with the Lean Selective Data Transition solution to migrate only future relevant business data
    • New Implementation using SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit SAP Cloud ERP Private and SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit SAP Cloud ERP Public - start fresh with master data and open items in a clean environment based on best practices
  5. Automated Data Validation
    Ensure data integrity with the data transition validation tool, using SAP‚Äôs standard reconciliation reports to verify completeness and correctness before and after the move. Accelerate your go-live decision during cutover.

Powered by SAP Cloud ALM, it delivers the tools, insights, and governance needed to lead transformation with confidence and clarity. The SAP Business Transformation Center is part of SAP's integrated toolchain.

To help you unlock the full potential of SAP‚Äôs transformation tools, we‚Äôve curated a set of learning journeys and courses designed to build your expertise and confidence.

Unlocking Change with SAP Business Transformation Center

Develop a comprehensive understanding of the Lean Selective Data Transition to SAP S/4HANA approach and its benefits using SAP Business Transformation Center. Learn which prerequisites are necessary and finally, gain insights into scoping, modeling, cycle and monitoring phase of a Lean Selective Data Transition to SAP S/4HANA with SAP Business Transformation.

  • Start the journey

Minimizing Downtime with Downtime-Optimized Conversion of SUM

Downtime during system conversion can impact business operations. Learn how to minimize it using the Downtime-Optimized Conversion of Software Update Manager (SUM) in this focused course.

  • Access the course

Migrating Data to SAP S/4HANA Using the Migration Cockpit

For S/4HANA or S/4HANA private cloud scenarios, the SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit offers a streamlined approach to data migration. This course provides hands-on guidance for using the cockpit effectively. This course includes system demos and covers topics such as adjusting migration objects, creating your own objects, and defining selection criteria. It also provides information sources for migration projects and future developments.

  •  Dive into the course

Migrating Data to SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition

This course provides an overview of the SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit, the tool for initial data load to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. It covers the features, functions, and best practices of the migration process, along with related apps. The course includes system demos based on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2302.

  • Explore the course

Mastering the Data Transition Validation Tool

By the end of this course, you will be able to use the data transition validation tool to validate the migrated business data during a transition to SAP S/4HANA or SAP S/4HANA upgrades and updates. 

  • Start the course

üí°Tip: Bookmark the SAP Learning site and check back regularly for new content and updates tailored to your transformation goals.

Have you tried any of these courses yet? Share your experience or ask questions in the comments below‚Äîlet‚Äôs learn together!

entry.title: Re: Route determination in Standard Purchase Order
entry.content: Hi Lakshmipathi, we are working on-premise platform application. Thanks for your input but in standard PO(NB) when you create an inbound delivery the transport data (route, shipping condition, loading date) need to enter manually in delivery since these data are not available in purchase order. But in our case, we need shipping condition and route to flow in inbound delivery from Purchase Order without any manual intervention. We also want to calculate loading date based on the route and delivery date in PO items.

entry.title: Custom logic for migrating for migrating information from BP Master Data to Billing Document

Hi,

I am facing a problem in which i need to migrate some informations from Customer Master Data to Balling Docuemnt, si they can be printed in the form template.

My code in custom logic is the following :

DATA LV_ICE TYPE STRING.
"bil_doc_res = bil_doc.
" READ from Importing
SELECT SINGLE TrainStationName
INTO @LV_ice
FROM YY1_ICE_INVOICE
WHERE CUSTOMER = @Bil_DOC-SOLDTOPARTY.
" WRITE to Changing
IF sy-subrc = 0 and bil_doc-YY1_ICE_BDH = ''."IS NOT INITIAL.
bil_doc_res-YY1_ICE_BDH = lv_ice.
ENDIF.

Thank you

entry.title: Run Statutory Reports App: fetches the data from the Archived database
entry.content:
Does the application run statutory reports App ID F1515 fetches the data from the Archived database or not?

 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Run Statutory Reports App: fetches the data from the...
entry.content:
Dear all,

 

Please note, data archiving is used to manage data at the end of its lifecycle in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition by blocking and deleting personal data. When the end of purpose is reached, personal data is moved from the database to archive files and is implicitly marked as blocked. Blocked data is subject to access restrictions to prevent further unauthorized processing

 

The 'Manage Archiving Variants' app, choose the archiving object and schedule archiving.

 

We can use the archiving object SRF_TASK for archiving reporting tasks in statutory reporting.

 

Please refer the below help document for more information,

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/4de200b26d5d42bbacae69c6bf6b9923/cb2ee9a6517f499299e8c03fad46e373.html?version=LATEST&locale=en-US

 

Best regards,

Atanu

SAP Support - S/4HANA Cloud

entry.title: Re: Run Statutory Reports App: fetches the data from the...
entry.content:
Dear all,

 

Please note, data archiving is used to delete data at the end of its lifecycle and to block and delete personal data in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Archiving moves the personal data from the database to archive files if the end of purpose is reached. In doing so, the personal data is implicitly marked as blocked. Blocked data has access restrictions to prevent further unauthorized processing.

 

The 'Manage Archiving Variants' app, choose the archiving object and schedule archiving.

 

We can use the archiving object SRF_TASK for archiving reporting tasks in statutory reporting.

 

Please refer the below help document for more information,

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/4de200b26d5d42bbacae69c6bf6b9923/cb2ee9a6517f499299e8c03fad46e373.html?version=LATEST&locale=en-US

 

Best regards,

Atanu

SAP Support - S/4HANA Cloud

entry.title: CSRF Token handling for ABAP Cloud Client Proxies
entry.content:
As on SAP S/4 HANA ‚â• 2025, we are able to create http clients as Tier 1 ABAP Cloud compatible syntax. From my research, the unified approach  for ABAP syntax that can run on Public Cloud & on-prem systems will require we use Communication Targets. For example:

DATA: lo_client_proxy TYPE REF TO /iwbep/if_cp_client_proxy,
      lo_http_client  TYPE REF TO if_web_http_client,
      lo_cota         TYPE REF TO /coss/cota_internal.

lo_cota = NEW /coss/cota_internal(  ).
lo_http_client = lo_cota->create_web_http_client( ).

lo_client_proxy = /iwbep/cl_cp_factory_remote=>create_v4_remote_proxy(
  EXPORTING
    is_proxy_model_key = VALUE #( repository_id = 'DEFAULT'
                                  proxy_model_id  = lv_proxy_model
                                  proxy_model_version = lv_model_vers )
    io_http_client             = lo_http_client
    iv_relative_service_root   = '/sap/opu/odata4/sap/....' ).

Behind the scenes, /coss/cota_internal will be created based on the ABAP version you are running. In our case, I am supporting Public Cloud & on-Prem 2025+.

For Public Cloud - Communication Targets require: 1) communication scenario, 2) communication arrangmement and communication system configuration. This scenario is testing correctly.

For On-Prem - Communication Targets (COTA) are automatically visible in transaction 'APPLDEST' and require an Application Destination be set-up underneath the COTA. For our purposes, we want to create the client proxy to read the local ABAP Application Server, therefore we point the application destination to our own system.

 

The code above to generate client proxies, continues to work for on-prem systems but when ->execute( ) hits, a CSRF exception hits. As ABAP Cloud developers our ability to manage CSRF tokens is tightly restricted as the framework is meant to manage their usage.



/iwbep/cl_cp_request explicitly blocking developers from setting a x-csrf-token fetch

How can we interact with SAP API Hub Client Proxies using on-stack ABAP Cloud Syntax for S/4 HANA 2025 and newer systems?

 



 

 

 

__PRESENT__PRESENT__PRESENT__PRESENT__PRESENT__PRESENT

entry.title: Re: Queries related to migrate SAP JAM to SF WorkZone
entry.content:
Hello Sharon

No legal successor product for SAP Jam Collaboration. SAP has however released alternative products - SAP Work Zone and SAP SuccessFactors Work Zone ‚Äì which provide many features known from SAP Jam Enterprise in addition to a broad range of additional capabilities, e.g., from SAP Business Technology Platform for application integration & extensibility.

If you decide to have SF WorkZone, yes you need to have a license for SF WorkZone.  (Answer point 1)

SAP Jam provides different manual and API-based options to export content, details can be found here: 

  • https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2618616 
  • https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2706983  

There is nothing specific documented for Non-SAP content, you will need to validate on a case-by-case basis. (Answer point 2) 

Tasks and To do list from SAP JAM will get lost. (Answer point 3)

entry.title: Re: Internal Error 5002 occurred when adding sales delivery
entry.content:
Check the following:

  • Verify status, expiry, and warehouse assignment for the problematic batch.
  • Check if the batch is correctly allocated and not already consumed.
  • Confirm that the batch quantity is truly available in the warehouse.
  • Review if any validation rules apply differently to certain batches.
  • If you have customizations, check the error log for more detail on the 5002 error.

entry.title: SAP Digital Manufacturing: Retrospective on release 2508
entry.content:
While the most recent 2511 release of SAP Digital Manufacturing is centered on targeted improvements to stability, scalability, and everyday usability in productive environments, it also provides a good moment to pause and look back. In this blog, I am taking a retrospective view on some of the key innovations delivered with release 2508.

Below is a concise, snackable collection of the main highlights from 2508, covering the improvements across Execution, Worker Experience, Demand, Edge, Insights, and Automation areas.

 

Execution

Collaboration link for consolidated goods issues
With release 2508, SAP Digital Manufacturing introduces a new collaboration link that enables consolidated goods issue (GI) posting for components at operation completion. Instead of integrating each individual component consumption, the GI is triggered once an operation is finally completed, independently of yield confirmation. This addresses scenarios where frequent or granular consumption postings would otherwise create unnecessary integration volume. This enhancement reduces ERP load, avoids redundant postings, and simplifies integration logic while still ensuring accurate material postings. It is particularly valuable for high-throughput environments where efficiency and reduced interface traffic are critical.

 

Data collection: Parameter type list
The new List parameter type in Data Collection allows predefined values to be selected from centrally managed data field lists. Instead of free-text input, users now select valid values during data collection, ensuring consistency and correctness of captured data. This directly addresses the risk of operator input errors and inconsistent values across production records. For businesses, this improves data quality, reduces rework caused by invalid entries, and speeds up data collection on the shop floor. It also lays a more reliable foundation for downstream analytics and quality reporting.

 

Data collection: Default value for parameter
This release also enables default values for Boolean and List-type data collection parameters. During execution, parameters now automatically default to a predefined value, which operators can override only if needed. This improvement targets repetitive data entry scenarios where the same value is entered repeatedly, causing inefficiencies and operator fatigue. From a business perspective, this results in faster execution steps, improved user experience, and reduced cognitive load for operators. Over time, it helps standardize data capture while maintaining flexibility for exceptions.

 

Inventory: New API for clearing inventory
A new public API is introduced to clear inventory in SAP Digital Manufacturing using plant and inventory ID. The API fully clears the on-hand quantity for inventories originating from ERP, EWM, or DM itself, without triggering external integrations. This addresses inventory inconsistencies that can occur due to rounding effects or process discrepancies between systems. For businesses, the API provides a controlled way to clean up excess or incorrect inventory balances in DM, ensuring system consistency and operational transparency. It supports cleaner inventory management without manual corrections or complex reconciliation steps.

 

Worker Experience

For Worker Experience area, I take a small step ahead and look at capabilities that are already available in beta today and are expected to become generally available with release 2605. These innovations give a good sense of where the shop floor user experience in SAP Digital Manufacturing is heading, with a clear focus on usability, flexibility, and support for compliance-driven scenarios.

New POD 2.0 Framework (GA in 2605)
With POD 2.0, SAP Digital Manufacturing introduces a new framework for shop floor user interfaces that focuses on performance, layout flexibility, and extensibility. The framework offers faster load times, a cleaner UI design, and a WYSIWYG-based layout approach that allows precise placement of controls and reuse of templates. This addresses longstanding pain points related to slow POD startup times, rigid layouts, and high custom development effort. From a business perspective, POD 2.0 reduces implementation and maintenance costs while improving operator efficiency on the shop floor. Its plugin-based architecture also creates a scalable foundation for future capabilities without requiring extensive redesign.

 New WYSIWYG Designer

Design Dialogues/Pages with HTML, Labels, Simple Forms, Plugins and iFrames

Integrate Production Processes bi-directionally

Use a high number of pre-configured actions to reduce custom efforts

Electronic Batch Record (EBR) (GA in 2605)
The Electronic Batch Record capability enables the creation, review, and approval of document-driven batch records directly within SAP Digital Manufacturing. It supports structured batch documentation with role-based authorization, versioning, and a comprehensive audit trail, enabling compliance-focused production scenarios. This addresses the challenge of managing batch documentation across multiple systems or through manual, paper-based processes. This way, EBR improves compliance with regulatory requirements such as GMP while reducing manual effort and documentation errors. It also establishes a consistent digital record that increases transparency, traceability, and readiness for audits.

Manage EBRs in POD 2.0 via multiple EBR specific plugins

 

Header Data, SFCs for the batch and a seamless Activity Log w/ e-signatures

 

Data scan: Barcode configuration & execution (GA in 2605 for production process integration) 
The data scan capability enables barcode-driven execution of production activities directly within the POD by configuring barcode parsing and mapping rules. Scanned barcodes can be interpreted using predefined structures and automatically trigger actions such as assembly, data collection, or SFC start, without additional manual steps. This addresses the inefficiency and error risk of manual data entry and navigation during execution. From a business standpoint, Data Scan reduces operator interaction time, accelerates production steps, and improves data accuracy on the shop floor. It also provides a scalable foundation for automation by reusing configurations across multiple execution scenarios.

 

SFC-based scheduling in Resource Orchestration
This release introduces SFC-based scheduling within Resource Orchestration, allowing schedules to be created and adjusted at the execution-object level rather than only at order level. SFCs can be scheduled directly on resources or work centers and executed seamlessly in the POD. This addresses the limitation of coarse-grained scheduling when frequent disruptions or mid-process adjustments occur on the shop floor. Speaking from the business perspective, SFC-based scheduling enables more precise control, faster reaction to disruptions, and better alignment between planning and execution. It is especially valuable in environments with high variability or short production cycles.

 

 

Switching between order-based and SFC-based scheduling
The planning board now allows planners to switch between order-based and SFC-based scheduling while maintaining consistent execution in the POD. This provides flexibility to plan at a higher level when stability is high and shift to detailed SFC scheduling when disruptions occur. This improves decision-making by allowing planners to choose the most appropriate planning granularity for the situation.

Multi-model planning board for heterogeneous objects
In 2508, the planning board is enhanced to support multiple execution object types, such as orders and SFCs, working under the same scheduling constraints. This enables heterogeneous objects to be visualized and scheduled together rather than in isolated planning contexts. The enhancement addresses scenarios where different production elements need to be coordinated on shared resources, such as in mill or continuous manufacturing industries. For businesses, this provides a more realistic and comprehensive scheduling view of the shop floor. It improves capacity utilization and reduces planning blind spots caused by fragmented scheduling models.

 

 

Public API for reading labor skills
A new public OData API is introduced to expose labor skill data from SAP Digital Manufacturing for external consumption. The API supports complex filtering and query structures that were previously difficult to handle through existing interfaces. This addresses the challenge of integrating skill-based scheduling or workforce analytics with external systems. For businesses, the API enables better workforce planning, advanced scheduling scenarios, and integration with third-party planning or analytics tools. It opens up skill data for broader reuse while maintaining a standardized and controlled access model.

 

Edge

Event-based business rules on Edge
With release 2508, SAP Digital Manufacturing Edge introduces event-based business rules that allow production processes running on the Edge to be triggered automatically based on Edge events. A new rule type, ‚ÄúEdge Event,‚Äù enables business logic defined in the cloud to be deployed and executed locally on the Edge. This addresses the limitation of relying solely on cloud-based triggers in scenarios where connectivity is unstable or latency-sensitive. This supports business continuity by allowing localized, automated reactions to shop floor events. It also improves transparency through the new Monitor Event Business Rules app available directly on the Edge.

 

 

Automated triggers and production processes on Edge
Automation on the Edge is further enhanced by allowing production processes to be triggered automatically through business rule evaluations. This enables logic-driven execution of processes directly at the Edge without manual intervention from operators. The enhancement addresses the need for faster, deterministic reactions to shop floor events, especially in decentralized manufacturing environments. For businesses, this reduces response times and manual workload on the shop floor. It also ensures that critical automation logic remains operational even when cloud connectivity is interrupted.

 

Print service in Edge production processes
Printing capabilities are now enabled directly within production processes running on the Edge. This allows documents such as labels or work instructions to be printed locally as part of an executed process step. Previously, printing often required external systems or manual workarounds, increasing complexity and error risk. For businesses, embedded print services improve process integration and reduce manual handling on the shop floor. This results in more streamlined execution flows and better alignment between digital processes and physical outputs.

 

Work instruction synchronization on Edge
Release 2508 also extends data synchronization on the Edge to include work instructions. This ensures that the latest work instructions are available locally, even when operating in disconnected or bandwidth-constrained environments. The innovation addresses reliance on constant cloud connectivity for operator guidance. From a business standpoint, synchronized work instructions improve execution consistency and reduce the risk of operators working with outdated information. It strengthens shop floor resilience by ensuring continuity of guided execution under varying network conditions.

Insights

Browser locale‚Äìbased descriptions in embedded analytics
With release 2508, SAP Digital Manufacturing enhances embedded analytics by supporting browser locale‚Äìbased description fields in embedded SAP Analytics Cloud dashboards. Description for fields such as material, reason code, time element, and standard value group are now displayed in the user‚Äôs browser language, provided the descriptions are maintained accordingly. This addresses the challenge of dashboards appearing incomplete or hard to interpret in multilingual production environments, a problem especially critical for customers tracking serialized materials where clear descriptions are vital. From a business perspective, the enhancement improves clarity and usability of operational reports for globally distributed teams. It enables faster and more accurate interpretation of data without requiring separate dashboards per language.

MDO and SFC report enhancements for improved traceability
The SFC Report and related MDOs are enhanced with additional production and traceability details in 2508. Hold and Hold Release events are now captured with user information and comments, and non-BOM components are included in the components view of the SFC Report. This closes gaps in production traceability where key events or consumed components were previously missing. For businesses, the enhancements provide a more complete audit trail of execution and material usage. They also improve report usability, supporting better root-cause analysis, compliance checks, and operational transparency.

 

Production connector and automation sequences as RESTful services
With release 2508, SAP Digital Manufacturing introduces enhanced RESTful capabilities for shop floor integration. The Production Connector can now be enabled as a RESTful service provider, allowing machines and systems on the shop floor to interact with SAP Digital Manufacturing via REST APIs. This is especially important for equipment that does not support OPC UA but still requires triggering of automation sequences or data exchange. By providing RESTful integration, businesses gain broader connectivity, simplified integration architectures, and reduced reliance on protocol-specific solutions, offering greater flexibility for connecting legacy or third-party systems.

Additionally, automation sequences designed in the Design Production Processes app can now be exposed as RESTful services. Once deployed, these sequences are accessible externally using HTTP or HTTPS, with configurable access types and detailed endpoints. This enables external systems to proactively trigger automation logic, moving beyond manual processes or polling mechanisms. For organizations, these enhancements support tighter integration between shop floor automation and higher-level systems such as MES extensions or custom applications, fostering more event-driven and responsive production operations.

 

Manage and monitor exposed automation services
Exposed automation sequences are now centrally visible in the Manage Service Registry app, including availability status and endpoint details. If a service is disabled, the system provides clear indicators to validate connector configuration and web server activation. This transparency addresses operational challenges related to troubleshooting and service governance. From a business standpoint, it improves reliability and maintainability of automation integrations. It also reduces downtime by enabling faster identification and resolution of connectivity issues.

Dynamic MQTT Topic Subscription and Publishing
In 2508, MQTT integration is enhanced to support dynamic subscription and publishing to broker topics. Previously, MQTT topics had to be statically maintained, limiting flexibility in event-driven automation scenarios. The new approach allows dynamic topic handling within automatic triggers and automation sequences. For businesses, this enables more scalable and adaptable messaging architectures. It supports complex event-driven use cases while reducing configuration overhead and increasing responsiveness on the shop floor.

 

Summary

Release 2508 delivered a series of focused innovations that strengthened execution, planning flexibility, and automation across the digital shop floor. While 2511 builds on this progress with a strong emphasis on stability and scalability, the capabilities introduced in 2508 continue to shape how manufacturers operate and integrate their production environments today. Looking back at these highlights shows how steady, purpose-driven innovation lays the groundwork for long-term operational excellence.

üé• Would you like to dive deeper into the innovations presented above?

Check out the recordings of our What's new sessions on Dispatching & Execution and Insights, Automation & Business Continuity.

entry.title: Re: ALV Sort Cell Merge Error
entry.content:
Cell merging is only performed if left part of the complete key is identical. If a previous columns are different, following cells that share the same value are not merged.

In your example, the value of the CON key is different, so the identical FLDATE values that follow are not merged.
